item.title: Classical period
item.description: mahAvIra the digambara munI, who gave up everything to conquer himself. buddha buddha gautama shramaNa, philosophical and social revolutionary, who (unfortunately) opened up paths towards Ananda to a broader section of the society. This led to an unfortunate increase in ascetic tendencies in hindu society. kAlIdAsa mahAkavi. sOmEshvara chAlukya the polymath author of manasollAsa. hemachandra-sUrI a vaishya by birth, brilliant grammarian in the chAlukya court - MT. mANikkavAchakar author of Tiruvachakam, who with his “sorcery” reputedly returned the Manichi nairs to the hindu fold from the Syrian church [Ar].

item.title: Indian republic
item.description: MS subbulakShmI MS subbulakShmI, daughter of a dEvadAsI, who remained a dEvadAsI in the truest sense, bhakti-vairAgya-saMpannA, divine voice who moved even the lay person and the foreigner to tears, bhArata-ratna. A great donor and patriot - who donated Masaysay award money to Phillipines, her new golden bangles towards the 1965 Indo-Pak war funds. Radhabinod Pal One of 3 asian judges who participated in the Tokyo trials after WW2 - the only one to hold all accused innocent.

item.title: Non brAhmaNa lines
item.description: गोत्र-प्रवर-विचारः Summary As late as the 11th c. AD, in the Gotra-Pravara-Manjari of Purusottama-Pandita, it is written as still prevalent that the gotra-pravara system applies to brahman (arsheya) lineages only: the Baudhayana-Pravara-Adhyaya mentions that the (biological) descendants of the seven rishis plus Agastya as the eighth are called gotra: this is the arsha-gotra (pita-putra parampara). The conventional sense is used as laukika-gotra (guru-shishya parampara/which non-brahmans use). Over the centuries, during to social and cultural changes, various groups in India have adopted the gotra system, but the pravara system still applies only to brahman gotras.

item.title: Rule of the European invaders
item.description: arumuka nalavAr arumuka nalavAr, the dvaita saiddhAntika shaiva, a brAhmaNa in deed despite not being born in the brAhmaNa-jAti, reprimanded the brAhmaNas of TN for the rate at which they were giving up the veda, who produced vigorous critiques of the Christianity and impeded missionary activity. - “Born as an ornament of the highly cultured and refined shaiva vELALa-s, he grew up to become a scholar in both tamizh and saMskRta.

item.title: The era of jihAds
item.description: The anonymous brAhmaNas who informed Ahmad ibn Yahya ibn Ishak al-Rawandi. kalhaNa kalhaNa, the kAshmIra-paNDita, to whom we owe the historical sentimental recollection rAja-tarangiNI. yAmunAchArya yAmunAchArya ALvandAr, clever debator and great perceptor (who incidentally authored a lost work on the kAshmIra-(pAncharAtrika)-Agama-prAmANya). bhAskarAchArya 2 the great polymath mathematician. gangAdevI daughter in law of the founder of vijayanagara, poetess author of madhurA-vijaya, which celebrates the recovery of dakShiNapatha from the jihAdI-s.
